Question 1: What concept, which the speaker's sister was introduced to at the age of five, is related to the scientific revolution in the way we look at the human brain? Options: A. Positive psychology, B. Cognitive psychology, C. Social psychology, D. Developmental psychology Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the speaker, what percentage of job successes are predicted by IQ? Options: A. 25%, B. 50%, C. 75%, D. 90% Correct Option: C
Question 3: What rare medical condition was the speaker's brother-in-law, Bobo, diagnosed with, even at Yale Medical School? Options: A. Leukemia, B. Leprosy, C. Cancer, D. HIV Correct Option: B
Question 4: What week was the speaker initially invited to speak at a prestigious boarding school, which focused on negative topics? Options: A. Wellness Week, B. Sickness Week, C. Happiness Week, D. Success Week Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the speaker, what is the problem with the formula for happiness and success that is widely followed? Options: A. It is too easy to achieve happiness and success., B. It is too difficult to achieve happiness and success., C. It is scientifically broken and backwards., D. It is not effective in the long term. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What term is used to describe the advantage that the brain experiences when it is positive, which leads to improved performance and productivity? Options: A. Happiness advantage, B. Positivity advantage, C. Success advantage, D. Productivity advantage Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is one of the ways that the speaker suggests training the brain to be more positive, which involves writing down three new things that one is grateful for each day? Options: A. Writing down three new things that one is grateful for each day, B. Journaling about one positive experience, C. Exercise, D. Meditation Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the speaker, what is the result of doing random acts of kindness or conscious acts of kindness, such as writing a positive email to someone in one's social support network? Options: A. It leads to a decrease in productivity., B. It leads to a decrease in happiness., C. It leads to a ripple effect of positivity., D. It leads to a decrease in creativity. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What term is used to describe the cultural ADHD that the speaker suggests is created by trying to do multiple tasks at once, which can be overcome through meditation? Options: A. Multitasking disorder, B. Attention deficit disorder, C. Cultural ADHD, D. Information overload Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the speaker, what is the goal of reversing the formula for happiness and success, which involves becoming positive in the present? Options: A. To achieve success at any cost., B. To become more competitive., C. To create a real revolution and create ripples of positivity., D. To become more productive. Correct Option: C
Question 11: According to the speaker, what is the main influence on long-term happiness, which is not predicted by the external world? Options: A. The external environment, B. Past experiences, C. The way the brain processes the world, D. The medical school syndrome Correct Option: C
Question 12: According to the speaker, what percentage of a Harvard student's happiness is predicted by their external environment? Options: A. 10%, B. 25%, C. 50%, D. 75% Correct Option: A
Question 13: According to the speaker, what is the main difference between the brain's view of the world and the Harvard student's brain's view of the world? Options: A. The speaker's brain views the world as a place of privilege, while the Harvard student's brain views the world as a place of competition., B. The speaker's brain views the world as a place of competition, while the Harvard student's brain views the world as a place of privilege., C. The speaker's brain views the world as a place of happiness, while the Harvard student's brain views the world as a place of stress., D. The speaker's brain views the world as a place of stress, while the Harvard student's brain views the world as a place of happiness. Correct Option: B
Question 14: According to the speaker, what is the main problem with the formula for happiness and success that is widely followed? Options: A. It is too easy to achieve happiness and success, and it is not related to dopamine., B. It is scientifically broken and backwards, and it is related to dopamine., C. It is too difficult to achieve happiness and success, and it is not related to dopamine., D. It is not effective in the long term, and it is related to dopamine. Correct Option: B
Question 15: According to the speaker, what is one of the ways that meditation can affect the brain? Options: A. Meditation allows the brain to focus on the task at hand., B. Meditation allows the brain to get over the cultural ADHD., C. Meditation allows the brain to adapt to the world in a different way., D. Meditation allows the brain to experience a happiness advantage. Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
Today lots of girls play sports. But, for a long time,
girls were not encouraged to kick, throw, run, jump, shoot, slide, or hit like boys. So, why did things change? And how much have they changed? Are girls and boys treated equally when it comes to sports? To begin to answer these questions, we have to look back. In 1972, Congress passed
a law called Title IX, which protected girls and women from discrimination in schools, colleges, and universities. This included discrimination
in school-sponsored sports. At that time, only 15%
of college athletes were women, and in high schools, only 7% of athletes were girls. Female athletes didn't get
a lot of support either and often had to provide
their own uniforms and equipment. It was Title IX that forced
school administrators to make sports more equal. But what does equal mean in sports? The government developed rules to measure equality
under two general categories: participation and treatment. In the early days of Title IX, the number of girls
playing sports was so low that it would have been very difficult for schools to suddenly provide
exactly the same number of opportunities for girls and boys. Instead, the government wrote rules that gave schools three options, or tests, to demonstrate fairness
in opportunities for girls. The three tests are proportionality, progress, and satisfied interests. A school can pick which test to follow. Proportionality means
that girls should receive the same percentage
of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls
in the student body. So, if 51% of students are girls, then girls should have approximately 51% of the opportunities to play sports. The second test, progress, requires schools to make up for the days when girls had fewer opportunities by adding new sports for girls
on a regular basis. The third test asks if girls interested in athletics are satisfied. Under this test, a school
must regularly ask female students what sports
they are interested in and also take into consideration
the popularity of certain sports in the area where the school is located. It must, then, add teams according
to the girls' interests. Another important part of Title IX is that it doesn't just look at how many athletic opportunities
are available to each sex but whether those opportunities
are of equal quality. Specifically, Title IX requires equality between boys and girls teams for things like equipment and supplies, publicity, the scheduling of games
and practice times, and the quality and number of coaches. Girls should also have equal access to locker rooms, practice spaces,
and competitive facilities, as well as medical services. So, if the best time to play
basketball is on Friday nights because that's when
most parents and fans can come, then the girls and boys teams should take turns playing on Friday night. If boys teams play
in a stadium with lights, scoreboards, and concession stands, then girls teams must have
the same opportunity, either by sharing those facilities or getting their own of equal quality. But, as we all know, just because a law exists doesn't mean that everybody follows it. School officials are responsible for making sure there
is fairness in sports, but you can help, too, by keeping an eye on your own school. Look around. Are there a lot more boys
than girls who play sports? Is the boys' soccer field
better than the girls'? Are athletic trainers available
to all teams equally? Does the baseball team get
new uniforms every year, while the softball team gets
them every three years? If you think there might be
inequality in your schools, you can approach a school administrator, a parent, or the Office of Civil Rights, a government agency
that makes sure schools comply with Title IX because equality
is important for everyone, both on the field and off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Title IX requires equivalent support for boys and girls areas in which of the following areas?
Options: A. Facilities, B. Equipment and supplies, C. Access to medical treatment, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
Today lots of girls play sports. But, for a long time,
girls were not encouraged to kick, throw, run, jump, shoot, slide, or hit like boys. So, why did things change? And how much have they changed? Are girls and boys treated equally when it comes to sports? To begin to answer these questions, we have to look back. In 1972, Congress passed
a law called Title IX, which protected girls and women from discrimination in schools, colleges, and universities. This included discrimination
in school-sponsored sports. At that time, only 15%
of college athletes were women, and in high schools, only 7% of athletes were girls. Female athletes didn't get
a lot of support either and often had to provide
their own uniforms and equipment. It was Title IX that forced
school administrators to make sports more equal. But what does equal mean in sports? The government developed rules to measure equality
under two general categories: participation and treatment. In the early days of Title IX, the number of girls
playing sports was so low that it would have been very difficult for schools to suddenly provide
exactly the same number of opportunities for girls and boys. Instead, the government wrote rules that gave schools three options, or tests, to demonstrate fairness
in opportunities for girls. The three tests are proportionality, progress, and satisfied interests. A school can pick which test to follow. Proportionality means
that girls should receive the same percentage
of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls
in the student body. So, if 51% of students are girls, then girls should have approximately 51% of the opportunities to play sports. The second test, progress, requires schools to make up for the days when girls had fewer opportunities by adding new sports for girls
on a regular basis. The third test asks if girls interested in athletics are satisfied. Under this test, a school
must regularly ask female students what sports
they are interested in and also take into consideration
the popularity of certain sports in the area where the school is located. It must, then, add teams according
to the girls' interests. Another important part of Title IX is that it doesn't just look at how many athletic opportunities
are available to each sex but whether those opportunities
are of equal quality. Specifically, Title IX requires equality between boys and girls teams for things like equipment and supplies, publicity, the scheduling of games
and practice times, and the quality and number of coaches. Girls should also have equal access to locker rooms, practice spaces,
and competitive facilities, as well as medical services. So, if the best time to play
basketball is on Friday nights because that's when
most parents and fans can come, then the girls and boys teams should take turns playing on Friday night. If boys teams play
in a stadium with lights, scoreboards, and concession stands, then girls teams must have
the same opportunity, either by sharing those facilities or getting their own of equal quality. But, as we all know, just because a law exists doesn't mean that everybody follows it. School officials are responsible for making sure there
is fairness in sports, but you can help, too, by keeping an eye on your own school. Look around. Are there a lot more boys
than girls who play sports? Is the boys' soccer field
better than the girls'? Are athletic trainers available
to all teams equally? Does the baseball team get
new uniforms every year, while the softball team gets
them every three years? If you think there might be
inequality in your schools, you can approach a school administrator, a parent, or the Office of Civil Rights, a government agency
that makes sure schools comply with Title IX because equality
is important for everyone, both on the field and off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following situations might indicate that a school is violating Title IX?
Options: A. Any athlete who is injured can make an appointment with the trainer, B. The football team is the only team to receive new uniforms every year, C. The girls and boys basketball teams take turns playing home games on Friday nights, D. The athletic director issues a press release promoting any team that makes it to post-season play
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Today lots of girls play sports. But, for a long time,
girls were not encouraged to kick, throw, run, jump, shoot, slide, or hit like boys. So, why did things change? And how much have they changed? Are girls and boys treated equally when it comes to sports? To begin to answer these questions, we have to look back. In 1972, Congress passed
a law called Title IX, which protected girls and women from discrimination in schools, colleges, and universities. This included discrimination
in school-sponsored sports. At that time, only 15%
of college athletes were women, and in high schools, only 7% of athletes were girls. Female athletes didn't get
a lot of support either and often had to provide
their own uniforms and equipment. It was Title IX that forced
school administrators to make sports more equal. But what does equal mean in sports? The government developed rules to measure equality
under two general categories: participation and treatment. In the early days of Title IX, the number of girls
playing sports was so low that it would have been very difficult for schools to suddenly provide
exactly the same number of opportunities for girls and boys. Instead, the government wrote rules that gave schools three options, or tests, to demonstrate fairness
in opportunities for girls. The three tests are proportionality, progress, and satisfied interests. A school can pick which test to follow. Proportionality means
that girls should receive the same percentage
of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls
in the student body. So, if 51% of students are girls, then girls should have approximately 51% of the opportunities to play sports. The second test, progress, requires schools to make up for the days when girls had fewer opportunities by adding new sports for girls
on a regular basis. The third test asks if girls interested in athletics are satisfied. Under this test, a school
must regularly ask female students what sports
they are interested in and also take into consideration
the popularity of certain sports in the area where the school is located. It must, then, add teams according
to the girls' interests. Another important part of Title IX is that it doesn't just look at how many athletic opportunities
are available to each sex but whether those opportunities
are of equal quality. Specifically, Title IX requires equality between boys and girls teams for things like equipment and supplies, publicity, the scheduling of games
and practice times, and the quality and number of coaches. Girls should also have equal access to locker rooms, practice spaces,
and competitive facilities, as well as medical services. So, if the best time to play
basketball is on Friday nights because that's when
most parents and fans can come, then the girls and boys teams should take turns playing on Friday night. If boys teams play
in a stadium with lights, scoreboards, and concession stands, then girls teams must have
the same opportunity, either by sharing those facilities or getting their own of equal quality. But, as we all know, just because a law exists doesn't mean that everybody follows it. School officials are responsible for making sure there
is fairness in sports, but you can help, too, by keeping an eye on your own school. Look around. Are there a lot more boys
than girls who play sports? Is the boys' soccer field
better than the girls'? Are athletic trainers available
to all teams equally? Does the baseball team get
new uniforms every year, while the softball team gets
them every three years? If you think there might be
inequality in your schools, you can approach a school administrator, a parent, or the Office of Civil Rights, a government agency
that makes sure schools comply with Title IX because equality
is important for everyone, both on the field and off.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which government agency is responsible for responding to Title IX complaints?
Options: A. The Environmental Protection Agency, B. The General Accounting Office, C. The Department of Education’s Office for Civil Rights, D. The Office of White House Counsel
Correct Option: C

Question: What did the seven-year-old Shawn do to avert the possibility of his parents waking up from their nap and finding Amy hurt?

Shawn pushed Amy to avoid her getting hit by an imaginary sniper bullet, D. Shawn made a deal with Amy that if she didn’t cry, she could pretend to be a unicorn in their game
Correct Option: B

disasters and very quickly my brain starts to think that's the accurate ratio of negative positive in the world what that's doing is creating something called the medical school syndrome which if you have leprosy which even at Yale is extraordinarily rare but I had no idea how to console poor Bobo because he had just gotten over an entire week of menopause see what we're finding is not necessarily the reality that shapes us but the lens to which your brain views the world that shapes your reality if we can change the lens not only can we change your happiness we can change every single educational and business outcome at the same time when I applied to Harvard I applied on it there I didn't expect to get in and my family had no money for college when I got a military scholarship two when I graduated after my four years and then spent the next eight years living in the dorms with the students Harvard asked me to wasn't that guy but what happened I was an officer of Harvard accounts those students through the difficult four years and what I found in my research my teaching is that these students no matter how happy they were with the original SAS success of getting into the school two weeks later the brains were focused not on the privilege of being there nor on their philosophy or their physics the brain was focused on the competition the workload the hassles the stresses the complaints when I first went in there I walked into the freshmen dining hall which is where my friends from Waco Texas which is where I grew up I know some of you've heard of it when I when they come to visit me they look around they say this freshman dining hall looks like something out of Hogwarts some movie Harry Potter which it does because Hogwarts and movie Harry Potter and that's Harvard when they see this they say Shawn why you waste your time studying happiness at Harvard seriously what does a Harvard student possibly have to be unhappy about embedded within that question is the key to understanding the science of happiness because what that question assumes is that our external world is predictive of our happiness levels when in reality if I know everything about your external world I can only predict 10% of your long-term happiness 90% of your long-term happiness is predicted not by the external world but by it through the way your brain processes the world and if we change it if we change our formula for happiness and success what we can do is change the way that we can then affect reality what we found is that only 25% of job successes are predicted by IQ 75 percent of job successes are predicted by your optimism levels your social support and your abilities see stress as a challenge instead of as a threat I talked to a boarding school up in New England probably the most prestigious boarding school and they said we already know that so every year instead of just teaching our students we also have a Wellness Week and we're so excited Monday night we have the world's leading expert coming in to speak about adolescent depression Tuesday night is school violence and bullying Wednesday night Wednesday nights eating disorders Thursday night is illicit drug user Friday night we're trying to decide between risky sex or happiness I said that's most people's Friday nights [Music] which I'm glad you like but they did not like that at all silence on the phone and into the silence I said I'd be happy to speak to your school but just you know that's not a Wellness week that's the sickness week what you've done is you've outlined all the negative things that can happen but not talked about the positive the absence of disease is not health here's how we get to health we need to reverse the formula for happiness and success in the past three years I've traveled to 45 different countries working with schools and companies in the midst of an economic downturn and what I found is the most companies and schools follow a formula for success which is this if I work harder I'll be more successful and if I'm more successful then I'll be happier that undergirds most of our parenting styles are managing style is the way that we motivate our behavior and the problem is it's scientifically broken and backwards for two reasons first every time your brain has a success you just change the goalposts of what success look like you got good grades now you have to get better grades it's gone to good schooling after you get a better school you got a good job now you have to get a better job you hit your sales target we're gonna change your sales target and if happiness is on the opposite side of success your brain never gets there what we've done is we pushed happiness over the cognitive horizon as a society and that's because we think we have to be successful successful then we'll be happier but the real problem is our brains work in the opposite order if you can raise somebody's level of positivity in the present then their brain experiences what we now call a happiness advantage which is your brain and positive perform significantly better than does a negative neutral stress your intelligence Rises your creativity Rises your energy levels rise in fact what we found is that every single business outcome improves your brain a positive is 31% more productive than it your brain and negative neutral stress you're 37% better at sales doctors are 19% faster more accurate at coming up with a correct diagnosis when positive instead of negative neutral stress which means we can reverse the formula if we can find a way becoming positive in the present then our brains work even more successfully as we're able to work harder faster and more intelligently what we need to be able to do is to reverse this formula so we can start to see what our brains are actually capable of because dopamine which floods into your system when you're positive has two functions not only does it make you happier it turns on all the learning centers in your brain allowing you to adapt to the world in a different way we found that there are ways you can train your brain to be able to come more positive in just a two minute span of time done for 21 days in row we can actually rewire your brain allowing your brain to actually work more optimistically and more successfully we've done these things in research now and every single company that I've worked with getting them to write down three new things that they're grateful for for 21 days in a row three new things each day and at the end of that their brain starts to retain a pattern of scanning the world not for the negative but for the positive first journaling about one positive experience you've had over the past 24 hours allows your brain to relive it exercise teaches your brain your behavior matters we find that meditation allows your brain to get over the cultural ADHD that we've been creating by trying to do multiple tasks at once and allows our brains to focus on the task at hand and finally random acts of kindness or conscious acts of kindness we get people when they open up their inbox to write one positive email praising or thanking somebody in their social support network and by doing these activities and by training your brain just like we trained our bodies what we found is we could reverse the formula for happiness and success and in doing so not only create ripples of positivity but create a real revolution thank you very much [Applause]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does Shawn Achor believe is the result of studying average cross-sections of groups?
Options: A. By studying what is average, we will not progress beyond that average, B. Studying the average individual creates normalcy, C. By studying average individuals, we can better diagnose problems during therapy, D. Studying the average person leads to progress and success
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Marianne North, and what did she do in 1860, and what was her motivation for traveling? Options: A. She was a botanist and painter who crossed the ocean to America with letters of introduction and a love of flowers, motivated by her desire to collect and paint new flowers., B. She was a photographer who traveled to Europe to study flowers, but her motivation was to see the world., C. She was a writer who went to Africa to study native customs., D. She was an explorer who traveled to the moon. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What motivated Alexandra David-Neel to visit the fabled city of Lhasa in Tibet, and what was her approach to achieving her goal? Options: A. She wanted to learn about the local culture and customs, and she approached her goal by following the rules and regulations., B. She wanted to prove herself to Parisian scholars of the day, and she approached her goal by disguising herself as a Tibetan man., C. She wanted to see the famous Himalayan mountains, and she approached her goal by traveling with a large entourage., D. She wanted to escape the rules and regulations of her society, and she approached her goal by being reckless and impulsive. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was unique about Mary Kingsley's journey to Africa, and what was her motivation for going? Options: A. She traveled with a large entourage of guides and assistants, and her motivation was to see the local wildlife., B. She was the first European to catalog many species of plants in the wild, and her motivation was to prove herself to her peers., C. She was a sheltered daughter who went against her family's wishes, and her motivation was to learn about native customs., D. She was a seasoned traveler who had been to Africa many times before, and her motivation was to escape the rules and regulations of her society. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What did Marianne North's paintings provide to botanists back in Europe, and what was the significance of her work? Options: A. Her paintings provided a glimpse of the local wildlife, but her work was not significant., B. Her paintings provided a catalog of the world's most unusual plants, and her work was significant because it helped botanists learn about new species., C. Her paintings provided a description of the local climate, but her work was not significant., D. Her paintings provided a map of the local geography, but her work was not significant. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the main obstacle that Alexandra David-Neel faced when she arrived at the border from India, and how did she overcome it? Options: A. She was forbidden to cross due to her nationality, and she overcame it by following the rules and regulations., B. She was forbidden to cross due to her disguise, and she overcame it by being clever and resourceful., C. She was forbidden to cross due to her lack of documents, and she overcame it by being persistent and determined., D. She was forbidden to cross due to her age, and she overcame it by being young and energetic. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was unique about Mary Kingsley's encounter with a hippopotamus, and how did she interact with it? Options: A. She was able to ride on its back, but that was not unique., B. She was able to feed it by hand, but that was not unique., C. She was able to tickle it with her umbrella, and that was unique., D. She was able to pet it gently, but that was not unique. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the main theme of the transcript, and how did the women in the story embody it? Options: A. The importance of travel and exploration, but the women in the story did not embody it., B. The power of curiosity and self-discovery, and the women in the story embodied it by being brave and determined., C. The challenges faced by women in society, but the women in the story did not embody it., D. The impact of photography on society, but the women in the story did not embody it. Correct Option: B
Question 8: Who was Alexandra David-Neel, what did she do to disguise herself, and what was the significance of her actions? Options: A. She was a Tibetan woman who dressed as a European man, but that was not significant., B. She was a European woman who dressed as a Tibetan man and wore a yak fur coat, and that was significant because it allowed her to achieve her goal., C. She was a local guide who wore a pair of sunglasses, but that was not significant., D. She was a monk who dressed as a monk and wore a traditional Tibetan robe, but that was not significant. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was the result of Alexandra David-Neel's journey to Lhasa, and what did she achieve? Options: A. She was able to write many books on Tibetan religion, but that was not the result of her journey., B. She was able to prove herself to Parisian scholars of the day, but that was not the result of her journey., C. She was able to see the famous Himalayan mountains, but that was not the result of her journey., D. She was able to write many books on Tibetan religion, which made a splash back in Paris and remain important today. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What was the significance of Marianne North's journey to America, and what did she achieve? Options: A. She was able to catalog many species of plants in the wild, but that was not the significance of her journey., B. She was able to travel to every continent except Antarctica, but that was not the significance of her journey., C. She was able to write many books on botany, but that was not the significance of her journey., D. She was able to travel to every continent except Antarctica, and she went on to paint many of the world's most unusual plants. Correct Option: D

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did Shawn Achor discover in his eight years counseling students at Harvard?
Options: A. Freshmen thrived psychologically, in large part due to the happiness they felt at being accepted to such a prestigious institution, B. Shortly after beginning their academic careers at Harvard, freshmen began to have a negative focus and lost their initial happiness of getting into the school, C. Harvard students were focused on their philosophies and maintained positive outlooks throughout their four years as undergraduates, D. The happiness of Harvard students was in direct relation to how difficult it had been for them to be accepted to the school
Correct Option: B

She was able to see the famous Himalayan mountains, but that was not the result of her journey., D. She was able to write many books on Tibetan religion, which made a splash back in Paris and remain important today. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What was the significance of Marianne North's journey to America, and what did she achieve? Options: A. She was able to catalog many species of plants in the wild, but that was not the significance of her journey., B. She was able to travel to every continent except Antarctica, but that was not the significance of her journey., C. She was able to write many books on botany, but that was not the significance of her journey., D. She was able to travel to every continent except Antarctica, and she went on to paint many of the world's most unusual plants. Correct Option: D

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Knowledge of every aspect of a subject’s external world would enable you to predict what about their long-term happiness?
Options: A. You would be able to predict 75% of their long-term happiness, B. You would be able to predict 90% of their long-term happiness, C. You would be able to predict 10% of their long-term happiness, D. Long-term happiness is unpredictable – it depends too much on circumstance
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Marianne North, and what did she do in 1860, and what was her motivation for traveling? Options: A. She was a botanist and painter who crossed the ocean to America with letters of introduction and a love of flowers, motivated by her desire to collect and paint new flowers., B. She was a photographer who traveled to Europe to study flowers, but her motivation was to see the world., C. She was a writer who went to Africa to study native customs., D. She was an explorer who traveled to the moon. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What motivated Alexandra David-Neel to visit the fabled city of Lhasa in Tibet, and what was her approach to achieving her goal? Options: A. She wanted to learn about the local culture and customs, and she approached her goal by following the rules and regulations., B. She wanted to prove herself to Parisian scholars of the day, and she approached her goal by disguising herself as a Tibetan man., C. She wanted to see the famous Himalayan mountains, and she approached her goal by traveling with a large entourage., D. She wanted to escape the rules and regulations of her society, and she approached her goal by being reckless and impulsive. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was unique about Mary Kingsley's journey to Africa, and what was her motivation for going? Options: A. She traveled with a large entourage of guides and assistants, and her motivation was to see the local wildlife., B. She was the first European to catalog many species of plants in the wild, and her motivation was to prove herself to her peers., C. She was a sheltered daughter who went against her family's wishes, and her motivation was to learn about native customs., D. She was a seasoned traveler who had been to Africa many times before, and her motivation was to escape the rules and regulations of her society. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What did Marianne North's paintings provide to botanists back in Europe, and what was the significance of her work? Options: A. Her paintings provided a glimpse of the local wildlife, but her work was not significant., B. Her paintings provided a catalog of the world's most unusual plants, and her work was significant because it helped botanists learn about new species., C. Her paintings provided a description of the local climate, but her work was not significant., D. Her paintings provided a map of the local geography, but her work was not significant. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the main obstacle that Alexandra David-Neel faced when she arrived at the border from India, and how did she overcome it? Options: A. She was forbidden to cross due to her nationality, and she overcame it by following the rules and regulations., B. She was forbidden to cross due to her disguise, and she overcame it by being clever and resourceful., C. She was forbidden to cross due to her lack of documents, and she overcame it by being persistent and determined., D. She was forbidden to cross due to her age, and she overcame it by being young and energetic. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was unique about Mary Kingsley's encounter with a hippopotamus, and how did she interact with it? Options: A. She was able to ride on its back, but that was not unique., B. She was able to feed it by hand, but that was not unique., C. She was able to tickle it with her umbrella, and that was unique., D. She was able to pet it gently, but that was not unique. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the main theme of the transcript, and how did the women in the story embody it? Options: A. The importance of travel and exploration, but the women in the story did not embody it., B. The power of curiosity and self-discovery, and the women in the story embodied it by being brave and determined., C. The challenges faced by women in society, but the women in the story did not embody it., D. The impact of photography on society, but the women in the story did not embody it. Correct Option: B
Question 8: Who was Alexandra David-Neel, what did she do to disguise herself, and what was the significance of her actions? Options: A. She was a Tibetan woman who dressed as a European man, but that was not significant., B. She was a European woman who dressed as a Tibetan man and wore a yak fur coat, and that was significant because it allowed her to achieve her goal., C. She was a local guide who wore a pair of sunglasses, but that was not significant., D. She was a monk who dressed as a monk and wore a traditional Tibetan robe, but that was not significant. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was the result of Alexandra David-Neel's journey to Lhasa, and what did she achieve? Options: A. She was able to write many books on Tibetan religion, but that was not the result of her journey., B. She was able to prove herself to Parisian scholars of the day, but that was not the result of her journey., C. She was able to see the famous Himalayan mountains, but that was not the result of her journey., D. She was able to write many books on Tibetan religion, which made a splash back in Paris and remain important today. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What was the significance of Marianne North's journey to America, and what did she achieve? Options: A. She was able to catalog many species of plants in the wild, but that was not the significance of her journey., B. She was able to travel to every continent except Antarctica, but that was not the significance of her journey., C. She was able to write many books on botany, but that was not the significance of her journey., D. success which is this if I work harder I'll be more successful and if I'm more successful then I'll be happier that undergirds most of our parenting styles are managing style is the way that we motivate our behavior and the problem is it's scientifically broken and backwards for two reasons first every time your brain has a success you just change the goalposts of what success look like you got good grades now you have to get better grades it's gone to good schooling after you get a better school you got a good job now you have to get a better job you hit your sales target we're gonna change your sales target and if happiness is on the opposite side of success your brain never gets there what we've done is we pushed happiness over the cognitive horizon as a society and that's because we think we have to be successful successful then we'll be happier but the real problem is our brains work in the opposite order if you can raise somebody's level of positivity in the present then their brain experiences what we now call a happiness advantage which is your brain and positive perform significantly better than does a negative neutral stress your intelligence Rises your creativity Rises your energy levels rise in fact what we found is that every single business outcome improves your brain a positive is 31% more productive than it your brain and negative neutral stress you're 37% better at sales doctors are 19% faster more accurate at coming up with a correct diagnosis when positive instead of negative neutral stress which means we can reverse the formula if we can find a way becoming positive in the present then our brains work even more successfully as we're able to work harder faster and more intelligently what we need to be able to do is to reverse this formula so we can start to see what our brains are actually capable of because dopamine which floods into your system when you're positive has two functions not only does it make you happier it turns on all the learning centers in your brain allowing you to adapt to the world in a different way we found that there are ways you can train your brain to be able to come more positive in just a two minute span of time done for 21 days in row we can actually rewire your brain allowing your brain to actually work more optimistically and more successfully we've done these things in research now and every single company that I've worked with getting them to write down three new things that they're grateful for for 21 days in a row three new things each day and at the end of that their brain starts to retain a pattern of scanning the world not for the negative but for the positive first journaling about one positive experience you've had over the past 24 hours allows your brain to relive it exercise teaches your brain your behavior matters we find that meditation allows your brain to get over the cultural ADHD that we've been creating by trying to do multiple tasks at once and allows our brains to focus on the task at hand and finally random acts of kindness or conscious acts of kindness we get people when they open up their inbox to write one positive email praising or thanking somebody in their social support network and by doing these activities and by training your brain just like we trained our bodies what we found is we could reverse the formula for happiness and success and in doing so not only create ripples of positivity but create a real revolution thank you very much [Applause]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is NOT a way to train your brain to become more positive?
Options: A. Performing conscious acts of kindness, B. Practicing meditation, C. Journaling about positive experiences, D. Setting increasingly higher goals for success
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Marianne North, and what did she do in 1860, and what was her motivation for traveling? Options: A. She was a botanist and painter who crossed the ocean to America with letters of introduction and a love of flowers, motivated by her desire to collect and paint new flowers., B. She was a photographer who traveled to Europe to study flowers, but her motivation was to see the world., C. She was a writer who went to Africa to study native customs., D. She was an explorer who traveled to the moon. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What motivated Alexandra David-Neel to visit the fabled city of Lhasa in Tibet, and what was her approach to achieving her goal? Options: A. She wanted to learn about the local culture and customs, and she approached her goal by following the rules and regulations., B. She wanted to prove herself to Parisian scholars of the day, and she approached her goal by disguising herself as a Tibetan man., C. She wanted to see the famous Himalayan mountains, and she approached her goal by traveling with a large entourage., D. She wanted to escape the rules and regulations of her society, and she approached her goal by being reckless and impulsive. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was unique about Mary Kingsley's journey to Africa, and what was her motivation for going? Options: A. She traveled with a large entourage of guides and assistants, and her motivation was to see the local wildlife., B. She was the first European to catalog many species of plants in the wild, and her motivation was to prove herself to her peers., C. She was a sheltered daughter who went against her family's wishes, and her motivation was to learn about native customs., D. She was a seasoned traveler who had been to Africa many times before, and her motivation was to escape the rules and regulations of her society. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What did Marianne North's paintings provide to botanists back in Europe, and what was the significance of her work? Options: A. Her paintings provided a glimpse of the local wildlife, but her work was not significant., B. Her paintings provided a catalog of the world's most unusual plants, and her work was significant because it helped botanists learn about new species., C. Her paintings provided a description of the local climate, but her work was not significant., D. Her paintings provided a map of the local geography, but her work was not significant. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the main obstacle that Alexandra David-Neel faced when she arrived at the border from India, and how did she overcome it? Options: A. She was forbidden to cross due to her nationality, and she overcame it by following the rules and regulations., B. She was forbidden to cross due to her disguise, and she overcame it by being clever and resourceful., C. She was forbidden to cross due to her lack of documents, and she overcame it by being persistent and determined., D. She was forbidden to cross due to her age, and she overcame it by being young and energetic. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was unique about Mary Kingsley's encounter with a hippopotamus, and how did she interact with it? Options: A. She was able to ride on its back, but that was not unique., B. She was able to feed it by hand, but that was not unique., C. She was able to tickle it with her umbrella, and that was unique., D. She was able to pet it gently, but that was not unique. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the main theme of the transcript, and how did the women in the story embody it? Options: A. The importance of travel and exploration, but the women in the story did not embody it., B. The power of curiosity and self-discovery, and the women in the story embodied it by being brave and determined., C. The challenges faced by women in society, but the women in the story did not embody it., D. The impact of photography on society, but the women in the story did not embody it. Correct Option: B
Question 8: Who was Alexandra David-Neel, what did she do to disguise herself, and what was the significance of her actions? Options: A. She was a Tibetan woman who dressed as a European man, but that was not significant., B. She was a European woman who dressed as a Tibetan man and wore a yak fur coat, and that was significant because it allowed her to achieve her goal., C. She was a local guide who wore a pair of sunglasses, but that was not significant., D. She was a monk who dressed as a monk and wore a traditional Tibetan robe, but that was not significant. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was the result of Alexandra David-Neel's journey to Lhasa, and what did she achieve? Options: A. She was able to write many books on Tibetan religion, but that was not the result of her journey., B. She was able to prove herself to Parisian scholars of the day, but that was not the result of her journey., C. She was able to see the famous Himalayan mountains, but that was not the result of her journey., D. She was able to write many books on Tibetan religion, which made a splash back in Paris and remain important today. Correct Option: D
Question 10: What was the significance of Marianne North's journey to America, and what did she achieve? Options: A. She was able to catalog many species of plants in the wild, but that was not the significance of her journey., B. She was able to travel to every continent except Antarctica, but that was not the significance of her journey., C. She was able to write many books on botany, but that was not the significance of her journey., D. She was able to travel to every continent except Antarctica, and she went on to paint many of the world's most unusual plants. Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Jessica Ruby Welcome to the Department of Plagiarism Investigation. The D.P.I. has dealt with numerous complex cases in their effort to bring plagiarists to justice and to rescue purloined texts. The first form of plagiarism that the D.P.I. regularly encounters is known as brain child snatching, in honor of the Latin word, plagiarius, from which plagiarism originates. Brain child snatchers sneak up on innocent papers and copy and paste them without citing any sources, putting quotation marks around direct quotes or changing a word. They've also been known to steal and hold particularly eloquent essays for ransom. When brain child snatchers get together, they form a kidnapping ring, which involves brain child snatching from multiple sources. Some perpetrators have even been known to commit self-plagiarism, one of the laziest crimes in the annals of the D.P.I. Also known as one-sided collaborators, these odd balls snatch up entire texts or small passages that they've written before and present them as brand-new material. Brain child snatchers and kidnapping rings are easy for the D.P.I. to catch. Just paste a few passages into a search engine, and BAM! They're caught red-handed. The more covert forms of plagiarism include the wild goose chase technique, in which plagiarists create fake authors, book titles, page numbers, or other information in order to cover up plagiarism. And the old synonym switcheroo in which plagiarists utilize a thesaurus as their main weapon. By substituting a synonym for nearly every word in the document and leaving the sentence structure and order of the ideas the same, plagiarists give legitimate paraphrasing a very bad name. Shoddy paraphrasing is also a key part of variations on a smokescreen, a technique in which multiple passages are paraphrased, then pasted together into one. The thorniest issue that the D.P.I. deals with is the misconception that you can never be accused of plagiarism if you use quotes and cite your sources. This is most certainly not the case because a paper that is made up of passage upon passage of other people's ideas is known as a wholly quotable document. This is considered plagiarism since there are no original thoughts in the work. Similarly, passage after passage of too closely paraphrased text from multiple cited sources is also plagiarism of the pervasively paraphrased kind because the ideas still aren't one's own. And lastly, the technique of revealing while concealing is plagiarism because it involves selective amnesia regarding one's sources in an attempt to cover up wholly quotable and pervasively paraphrased issues in a text. Some passages are meticulously documented, quoted, or paraphrased, while others are presented entirely as one's own. As you can see, the D.P.I. has its hands full, tackling all sorts of academic mischief and mayhem, ranging from the petty to the outrageous. Given the gravity of these transgressions, you might be wondering why you've never heard of the Department of Plagiarism Investigation's victories. That's because it doesn't technically exist. But people, like you and me, can be our own D.P.I. agents to fight plagiarism and uphold the values of original thinking. We know that the best defense against plagiarism consists of writers who save themselves time, worry, and effort by taking the far easier road of just doing the work themselves.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Renee, the daughter of a U.S. DPI secret agent, procrastinated all semester and started her creative writing project the night before. Renee looked up a random poet online and copied and pasted her poems into her project, claiming them as her own original poems. Renee engaged in the most egregious form of plagiarism, according to the DPI.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the purpose of the experiment that Matt conducted with his listeners? Options: A. To test their ability to follow directions, B. To explore the concept of time perception, C. To study the effects of laughter on the brain, D. To investigate the impact of music on memory Correct Option: B
Question 2: What action did Matt ask his listeners to take on the count of three? Options: A. To stand up and stretch, B. To hop on one foot, C. To clap their hands, D. To take a deep breath Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to David Eagleman, what influences time perception? Options: A. The number of memories and data stored in the brain, B. The amount of physical exercise one engages in, C. The type of music one listens to, D. The amount of sleep one gets Correct Option: A
Question 4: Why do people often miscalculate time when experiencing something new or dynamic? Options: A. Because their brains follow a straight line between two points, B. Because their brains follow a curved path that is dependent on the amount of information they take in, C. Because they are not paying attention, D. Because they are not interested Correct Option: B
Question 5: What happens when we have a new experience, like jumping off a high dive for the first time? Options: A. Our senses are dulled, B. We take in less details about sights, sounds, and smells, C. We store more data onto our brain in the form of memories, D. We feel no emotions Correct Option: C
Question 6: According to Matt, what is the impact of time perception on our lives? Options: A. It makes us feel like time is passing slowly, B. It makes us feel like time is passing quickly, C. It teaches us why we shouldn't sit on a couch and let life pass us by, D. It has no impact on our lives Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why do children often feel like their childhood lasted forever? Options: A. Because they were bored, B. Because they were not interested in learning, C. Because they recorded more data onto their brains, D. Because they were not paying attention Correct Option: C
Question 8: What happens to our perception of time as we get older? Options: A. It stays the same, B. It gets faster, C. It gets slower, D. It depends on the amount of memories and data we store Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to Matt, what is a lesson that time perception teaches us? Options: A. To sit on a couch and let life pass us by, B. To get up and engage with the world and have new experiences, C. To focus on the present moment, D. To worry about the future Correct Option: B
Question 10: Why does time perception provide a great lesson for us on how to live our lives? Options: A. Because it teaches us to be lazy, B. Because it teaches us to be patient, C. Because it teaches us to engage with the world and have new experiences, D. Because it has no impact on our lives Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The generated MCQs appear to be related to a different topic, such as time perception, and do not address the topic of plagiarism.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the format and structure of the question, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ.

But if you insist on an answer, I would say that Question 1 is the most similar, but only because it is the first question and has a similar format, not because of the content or intent.

Index: 1 (Note: This is not a good match, and the generated MCQs need to be revised to match the ground truth MCQs)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Lee forgets to write down the details regarding the online sources, interview subjects, and other information she used as she gathered information for her blog about the DPI’S Most Wanted Plagiarists. Running out of time, Lee decides to fabricate the entire works cited section at the end of the blog post. What type of plagiarism did she commit?
Options: A. The Kidnapping Ring, B. One-Sided Collaboration, C. Wild Goose Chase, D. The Old Synonym Switcheroo
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Jessica Ruby Welcome to the Department of Plagiarism Investigation. The D.P.I. has dealt with numerous complex cases in their effort to bring plagiarists to justice and to rescue purloined texts. The first form of plagiarism that the D.P.I. regularly encounters is known as brain child snatching, in honor of the Latin word, plagiarius, from which plagiarism originates. Brain child snatchers sneak up on innocent papers and copy and paste them without citing any sources, putting quotation marks around direct quotes or changing a word. They've also been known to steal and hold particularly eloquent essays for ransom. When brain child snatchers get together, they form a kidnapping ring, which involves brain child snatching from multiple sources. Some perpetrators have even been known to commit self-plagiarism, one of the laziest crimes in the annals of the D.P.I. Also known as one-sided collaborators, these odd balls snatch up entire texts or small passages that they've written before and present them as brand-new material. Brain child snatchers and kidnapping rings are easy for the D.P.I. to catch. Just paste a few passages into a search engine, and BAM! They're caught red-handed. The more covert forms of plagiarism include the wild goose chase technique, in which plagiarists create fake authors, book titles, page numbers, or other information in order to cover up plagiarism. And the old synonym switcheroo in which plagiarists utilize a thesaurus as their main weapon. By substituting a synonym for nearly every word in the document and leaving the sentence structure and order of the ideas the same, plagiarists give legitimate paraphrasing a very bad name. Shoddy paraphrasing is also a key part of variations on a smokescreen, a technique in which multiple passages are paraphrased, then pasted together into one. The thorniest issue that the D.P.I. deals with is the misconception that you can never be accused of plagiarism if you use quotes and cite your sources. This is most certainly not the case because a paper that is made up of passage upon passage of other people's ideas is known as a wholly quotable document. This is considered plagiarism since there are no original thoughts in the work. Similarly, passage after passage of too closely paraphrased text from multiple cited sources is also plagiarism of the pervasively paraphrased kind because the ideas still aren't one's own. And lastly, the technique of revealing while concealing is plagiarism because it involves selective amnesia regarding one's sources in an attempt to cover up wholly quotable and pervasively paraphrased issues in a text. Some passages are meticulously documented, quoted, or paraphrased, while others are presented entirely as one's own. As you can see, the D.P.I. has its hands full, tackling all sorts of academic mischief and mayhem, ranging from the petty to the outrageous. Given the gravity of these transgressions, you might be wondering why you've never heard of the Department of Plagiarism Investigation's victories. That's because it doesn't technically exist. But people, like you and me, can be our own D.P.I. agents to fight plagiarism and uphold the values of original thinking. We know that the best defense against plagiarism consists of writers who save themselves time, worry, and effort by taking the far easier road of just doing the work themselves.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Suppose that in the previous example Mary had included no quotes, but she had paraphrased almost every line in the paper and properly cited it. Would this also be considered plagiarism?
Options: A. Yes, B. No
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the purpose of the experiment that Matt conducted with his listeners? Options: A. To test their ability to follow directions, B. To explore the concept of time perception, C. To study the effects of laughter on the brain, D. To investigate the impact of music on memory Correct Option: B
Question 2: What action did Matt ask his listeners to take on the count of three? Options: A. To stand up and stretch, B. To hop on one foot, C. To clap their hands, D. To take a deep breath Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to David Eagleman, what influences time perception? Options: A. The number of memories and data stored in the brain, B. The amount of physical exercise one engages in, C. The type of music one listens to, D. The amount of sleep one gets Correct Option: A
Question 4: Why do people often miscalculate time when experiencing something new or dynamic? Options: A. Because their brains follow a straight line between two points, B. Because their brains follow a curved path that is dependent on the amount of information they take in, C. Because they are not paying attention, D. Because they are not interested Correct Option: B
Question 5: What happens when we have a new experience, like jumping off a high dive for the first time? Options: A. Our senses are dulled, B. We take in less details about sights, sounds, and smells, C. We store more data onto our brain in the form of memories, D. We feel no emotions Correct Option: C
Question 6: According to Matt, what is the impact of time perception on our lives? Options: A. It makes us feel like time is passing slowly, B. It makes us feel like time is passing quickly, C. It teaches us why we shouldn't sit on a couch and let life pass us by, D. It has no impact on our lives Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why do children often feel like their childhood lasted forever? Options: A. Because they were bored, B. Because they were not interested in learning, C. Because they recorded more data onto their brains, D. Because they were not paying attention Correct Option: C
Question 8: What happens to our perception of time as we get older? Options: A. It stays the same, B. It gets faster, C. It gets slower, D. It depends on the amount of memories and data we store Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to Matt, what is a lesson that time perception teaches us? Options: A. To sit on a couch and let life pass us by, B. To get up and engage with the world and have new experiences, C. To focus on the present moment, D. To worry about the future Correct Option: B
Question 10: Why does time perception provide a great lesson for us on how to live our lives? Options: A. Because it teaches us to be lazy, B. Because it teaches us to be patient, C. Because it teaches us to engage with the world and have new experiences, D. Because it has no impact on our lives Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. The generated MCQs appear to be related to a different topic, such as time perception, and do not address the concept of plagiarism.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the question format (yes/no or A/B options), I would say that none of the generated MCQs have a similar format.

To provide a meaningful answer, I would need generated MCQs that are related to the topic of plagiarism. If you provide a new set of generated MCQs that are relevant to the topic, I would be happy to help you identify the most similar one.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Jessica Ruby Welcome to the Department of Plagiarism Investigation. The D.P.I. has dealt with numerous complex cases in their effort to bring plagiarists to justice and to rescue purloined texts. The first form of plagiarism that the D.P.I. regularly encounters is known as brain child snatching, in honor of the Latin word, plagiarius, from which plagiarism originates. Brain child snatchers sneak up on innocent papers and copy and paste them without citing any sources, putting quotation marks around direct quotes or changing a word. They've also been known to steal and hold particularly eloquent essays for ransom. When brain child snatchers get together, they form a kidnapping ring, which involves brain child snatching from multiple sources. Some perpetrators have even been known to commit self-plagiarism, one of the laziest crimes in the annals of the D.P.I. Also known as one-sided collaborators, these odd balls snatch up entire texts or small passages that they've written before and present them as brand-new material. Brain child snatchers and kidnapping rings are easy for the D.P.I. to catch. Just paste a few passages into a search engine, and BAM! They're caught red-handed. The more covert forms of plagiarism include the wild goose chase technique, in which plagiarists create fake authors, book titles, page numbers, or other information in order to cover up plagiarism. And the old synonym switcheroo in which plagiarists utilize a thesaurus as their main weapon. By substituting a synonym for nearly every word in the document and leaving the sentence structure and order of the ideas the same, plagiarists give legitimate paraphrasing a very bad name. Shoddy paraphrasing is also a key part of variations on a smokescreen, a technique in which multiple passages are paraphrased, then pasted together into one. The thorniest issue that the D.P.I. deals with is the misconception that you can never be accused of plagiarism if you use quotes and cite your sources. This is most certainly not the case because a paper that is made up of passage upon passage of other people's ideas is known as a wholly quotable document. This is considered plagiarism since there are no original thoughts in the work. Similarly, passage after passage of too closely paraphrased text from multiple cited sources is also plagiarism of the pervasively paraphrased kind because the ideas still aren't one's own. And lastly, the technique of revealing while concealing is plagiarism because it involves selective amnesia regarding one's sources in an attempt to cover up wholly quotable and pervasively paraphrased issues in a text. Some passages are meticulously documented, quoted, or paraphrased, while others are presented entirely as one's own. As you can see, the D.P.I. has its hands full, tackling all sorts of academic mischief and mayhem, ranging from the petty to the outrageous. Given the gravity of these transgressions, you might be wondering why you've never heard of the Department of Plagiarism Investigation's victories. That's because it doesn't technically exist. But people, like you and me, can be our own D.P.I. agents to fight plagiarism and uphold the values of original thinking. We know that the best defense against plagiarism consists of writers who save themselves time, worry, and effort by taking the far easier road of just doing the work themselves.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Trudi takes a properly cited paper that she wrote two years ago for an anthropology course, changes the date in the heading, and turns it in for a history course.
Options: A. One-sided Collaboration, B. Variations on a Smokescreen, C. Wholly Quotable, D. She didn’t commit plagiarism since she wrote the original paper!
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: What action did Matt ask his listeners to take on the count of three? Options: A. To stand up and stretch, B. To hop on one foot, C. To clap their hands, D. To take a deep breath Correct Option: B

Question 5: What happens when we have a new experience, like jumping off a high dive for the first time? Options: A. Our senses are dulled, B. We take in less details about sights, sounds, and smells, C. We store more data onto our brain in the form of memories, D. We feel no emotions Correct Option: C

It teaches us why we shouldn't sit on a couch and let life pass us by, D. It has no impact on our lives Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why do children often feel like their childhood lasted forever? Options: A. Because they were bored, B. Because they were not interested in learning, C. Because they recorded more data onto their brains, D. Because they were not paying attention Correct Option: C
